[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Trait: Deref for NormalizedPath] [Mutation Risk] Does dereferencing NormalizedPath to PathBuf expose any APIs that could modify the path in-place, breaking the normalization invariant maintained by NormalizedPath? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Trait: AsRef for NormalizedPath] [Security Boundary Violation] Can AsRef<Path> conversion be used to pass NormalizedPath to functions expecting Path, circumventing type-based security checks that distinguish between normalized and unnormalized paths? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Trait: Eq/PartialEq for NormalizedPath] [Case Sensitivity Issues] On case-insensitive filesystems, can NormalizedPath equality checks fail to match paths that actually refer to the same file, allowing duplicate module imports or bypassing uniqueness constraints? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Trait: Ord/PartialOrd for NormalizedPath] [Sort Order Manipulation] Can an attacker craft normalized paths with specific string properties that sort in unexpected orders, manipulating the sequence in which Move packages are processed and potentially changing compilation outcomes? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Overall Design] [No Length Limits] Are there any length limits on paths processed by normalize_path() and CanonicalPath::new(), or can arbitrarily long paths cause buffer overflows, stack exhaustion, or performance degradation? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Overall Design] [No Content Validation] Does the file perform any validation that paths point to legitimate Move package files rather than executables, scripts, or malicious binaries that could be loaded as dependencies? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Overall Design] [Missing Sandbox Checks] Is there any enforcement that canonical and normalized paths remain within a designated sandbox directory for Move packages, or can they resolve to arbitrary system locations? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Overall Design] [Thread Safety] Are CanonicalPath and NormalizedPath thread-safe when used concurrently across multiple validator threads during parallel package compilation, or can race conditions occur? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/path.rs] [Overall Design] [Error Propagation] When CanonicalPath::new() returns an error via Result<Self>, how is this handled by calling code - can error conditions be exploited to skip path validation or cause unsafe fallback behaviors?
